verses.text: Give ear, O heavens, and I will speak; let the earth hear the words of my mouth.
verses.comment: Heavens and earth are called as witnesses—common in ancient treaties and poetry.

verses.text: Let my teaching fall like rain, my speech drop down like dew, like gentle rain on new grass, and showers upon the herb.
verses.comment: Rain and dew as metaphors for refreshment and life-giving instruction.

verses.text: For I will proclaim the name of the LORD; ascribe greatness to our God!
verses.comment: Proclaiming God’s name—declaring His nature and works.

verses.text: The Rock—His work is perfect, for all His ways are justice; a faithful God, without iniquity, just and upright is He.
verses.comment: "The Rock" is a title emphasizing God’s stability and dependability.

verses.text: They have acted corruptly toward Him; they are not His children, because of their blemish. They are a crooked and twisted generation.
verses.comment: "Blemish" or defect refers to moral fault.

verses.text: Do you thus repay the LORD, O foolish and unwise people? Is He not your Father, who created you, who made you and established you?
verses.comment: God as father—implying His role as creator and sustainer.

verses.text: Remember the days of old, consider the generations long past. Ask your father, and he will show you; your elders, and they will tell you.
verses.comment: Emphasis on oral tradition and communal memory.

verses.text: When the Most High gave to the nations their inheritance, when He separated the children of man, He fixed the borders of the peoples according to the number of the sons of Israel.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts say "sons of God" or "angels of God." 'Sons of Israel' reflects the Masoretic Text; 'sons of God' is found in Dead Sea Scrolls and LXX.

verses.text: But the LORD’s portion is His people; Jacob is the allotment of His inheritance.
verses.comment: Israel as God’s chosen inheritance.

verses.text: He found him in a desert land, in a howling wasteland; He encircled him, cared for him, kept him as the apple of His eye.
verses.comment: “Apple of His eye” refers to precious protection.

verses.text: Like an eagle that stirs up its nest, that hovers over its young, He spread His wings, caught them, carried them on His pinions.
verses.comment: God’s care likened to a mother eagle.

verses.text: The LORD alone guided him; no foreign god was with him.
verses.comment: Stresses monotheism.

verses.text: He made him ride on the heights of the land, and he ate the produce of the fields; He made him suck honey out of the rock, and oil out of the flinty rock;
verses.comment: Poetic imagery for abundance and provision.

verses.text: Curds from the herd, and milk from the flock, with fat of lambs, rams of Bashan and goats, with the finest wheat— and you drank wine from the blood of the grape.
verses.comment: "Blood of the grape" is a Hebrew idiom for wine.

verses.text: But Jeshurun grew fat, and kicked; you grew fat, stout, and sleek. Then he abandoned God who made him and rejected the Rock of his salvation.
verses.comment: "Jeshurun" is a poetic name for Israel, used in parallel with their waywardness.

verses.text: They provoked Him to jealousy with strange gods; with abominations they angered Him.
verses.comment: Idolatry expressed in covenant language ('provoked to jealousy').

verses.text: They sacrificed to demons, not to God, to gods they had not known, to new ones that had come lately, whom your fathers did not fear.
verses.comment: "Demons" literally 'destroyers,' indicating the spiritual reality behind idolatry.

verses.text: You forgot the Rock who gave you birth, and forgot the God who brought you forth.
verses.comment: Forgetting God as creator/parent.

verses.text: The LORD saw it and spurned them, because of the provocation of His sons and His daughters.
verses.comment: God’s rejection in response to rebellion.

verses.text: He said, 'I will hide My face from them; I will see what their end will be. For they are a perverse generation, children in whom is no faithfulness.'
verses.comment: "Hide My face" refers to withdrawal of divine favor or presence.

verses.text: They have made Me jealous with what is not God; they have provoked Me to anger with their idols. So I will make them jealous with those who are not a people; I will provoke them to anger with a foolish nation.
verses.comment: A prophecy of God using foreign nations to chastise Israel.

verses.text: For a fire is kindled by My anger, and burns to the depths of Sheol, devours the earth and its increase, and sets on fire the foundations of the mountains.
verses.comment: "Sheol" refers to the grave or realm of the dead.

verses.text: I will heap disasters upon them; I will spend My arrows on them;
verses.comment: Arrows symbolize calamities or judgments.

verses.text: They will be wasted with hunger, devoured by plague and bitter destruction. I will send the teeth of beasts against them, with the venom of crawling things of the dust.
verses.comment: Typical covenantal punishments: famine, disease, wild animals.

verses.text: Outside the sword shall bereave, and inside terror— for both young man and young woman, the nursing child with the man of gray hairs.
verses.comment: Describes all perishing in national disaster.

verses.text: I said, "I would scatter them to the farthest corners; I would make the memory of them cease from among men,"
verses.comment: An allusion to exile.

verses.text: Had I not feared the provocation of the enemy, lest their adversaries misunderstand, lest they say, 'Our hand is exalted, and it is not the LORD who has done all this.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy is tied to His name and reputation.

verses.text: For they are a nation void of counsel, and there is no understanding in them.
verses.comment: Describes Israel’s lack of understanding.

verses.text: If only they were wise, they would understand this; they would discern their latter end!
verses.comment: "Latter end" can mean outcome or fate.

verses.text: How could one chase a thousand, and two put ten thousand to flight, unless their Rock had sold them, unless the LORD had given them up?
verses.comment: "Rock sold them" means God withdrew His protection.

verses.text: For their rock is not like our Rock; even our enemies themselves judge this.
verses.comment: Contrast between Israel’s God and the gods of the nations.

verses.text: For their vine is from the vine of Sodom, and from the fields of Gomorrah; their grapes are poison grapes, their clusters are bitter.
verses.comment: Sodom and Gomorrah as symbols of moral corruption.

verses.text: Their wine is the venom of serpents, and the deadly poison of cobras.
verses.comment: Describes Israel’s idolatry as destructive.

verses.text: 'Is not this laid up in store with Me, sealed up among My treasures?'
verses.comment: God’s judgment is delayed but certain—"treasured up" for later.

verses.text: Vengeance is Mine, and recompense, for the time when their foot slips; for the day of their disaster is near, and their doom comes quickly.
verses.comment: Quoted in NT as a warning of God’s impartial judgment.

verses.text: For the LORD will vindicate His people and have compassion on His servants, when He sees that their strength is gone and there is none remaining, bond or free.
verses.comment: 'Bond or free' means everyone is weak and helpless.

verses.text: Then He will say: 'Where are their gods—the rock in which they took refuge,'
verses.comment: God mocks the idols’ inability to save.

verses.text: who ate the fat of their sacrifices, and drank the wine of their drink offerings? Let them rise up and help you! Let them be your protection!
verses.comment: Repeated polemic against useless idols.

verses.text: See now that I, even I, am He, and there is no god besides Me. I kill and I make alive; I wound and I heal; and there is none who can deliver out of My hand.
verses.comment: God’s absolute sovereignty over life and death.

verses.text: For I lift up My hand to heaven and swear: as I live forever,
verses.comment: "Lift up My hand"—an oath formula.

verses.text: if I sharpen My flashing sword and My hand takes hold in judgment, I will take vengeance on My adversaries and repay those who hate Me.
verses.comment: "Flashing sword"—judgment imagery.

verses.text: I will make My arrows drunk with blood, and My sword will devour flesh— with the blood of the slain and the captives, from the long-haired heads of the enemy.
verses.comment: 'Long-haired heads' refers poetically to warriors or leaders.

verses.text: Rejoice, O nations, with His people, for He will avenge the blood of His servants, He will take vengeance on His adversaries and atone for His land and His people.
verses.comment: Some ancient versions add extra phrases—this follows the Masoretic Text.

verses.text: Moses came with Joshua the son of Nun and spoke all the words of this song in the hearing of the people.
verses.comment: Joshua’s presence is emphasized.

verses.text: When Moses had finished speaking all these words to all Israel,
verses.comment: Transition phrase, typical in Deuteronomy.

verses.text: he said to them, 'Set your hearts on all these words which I testify among you today, so that you may command your children to obey all the words of this law.
verses.comment: Passing the teaching to the next generation.

verses.text: For it is no empty word for you, but your life, and by this word you shall live long in the land that you are going over the Jordan to possess.'
verses.comment: "Empty word" means it’s not meaningless—God’s law brings real life.

verses.text: On that very day the LORD spoke to Moses,
verses.comment: Introduction to the LORD’s command to Moses about his death.

verses.text: 'Go up this mountain of the Abarim, Mount Nebo, which is in the land of Moab, across from Jericho, and view the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the people of Israel for a possession;
verses.comment: Mount Nebo is east of the Jordan River.

verses.text: and die on the mountain where you go up, and be gathered to your people, as Aaron your brother died on Mount Hor and was gathered to his people;
verses.comment: "Gathered to your people" refers to afterlife with ancestors.

verses.text: because you broke faith with Me in the midst of the people of Israel at the waters of Meribah-Kadesh, in the wilderness of Zin; because you did not sanctify Me in the midst of the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Refers to the incident where Moses struck the rock—see Numbers 20.

verses.text: For you shall see the land before you, but you shall not go there, into the land that I am giving to the people of Israel.'
verses.comment: Moses only sees, not enters, the Promised Land due to previous disobedience.
